node.title: Add support for local file system repos (in the `docker-compose`/local experience)

node.bodyText:
This can be achieved by creating an override docker-compose.override.yaml file locally (by the end user) and adding a bind-mount volume.
services:
  worker:
    volumes:
      - ~/projects:/projects # this can be any local path
Then, from the UI, the repository can be added by using a file:// url:
I had some trouble in this setup when it came to running the GIT_* sync types - were you able to get data syncing okay locally @riyaz-ali? I added the volumes to the docker-compose file locally.
Ah! sorry my bad. You need an additional / after the scheme, such that the path reads /projects/mergestat. The full url would be file:///projects/mergestat

Got it! Thanks - I was able to validate that! Really cool that we can support this in an ok way for now. So I think for this ticket let's mark it complete when we've:

Documented in our docs (maybe in the Running Locally section? Or Setup section? @amenowanna what do you think)
Documented in the docker-compose.yaml file with a comment (let's include an example of how to mount a volume to the worker and a link to the docs page)

Anything else?
We should put the docs in the running locally section. In general we still need to add docs for adding individual repos and those docs could link to the running local docs for people looking to that.
@riyaz-ali please finish creating the docs for this so we can get flow moving on this issue again and moved to done.

node.title: Need help how can I fix gitsync timeout issue

node.bodyText:
Hi @kapilkumawat86 - at the moment there's not a way to filter data at collection/sync time (though that is something we should add support for via user-defined configuration of our syncs).
Something you could do to address this particular issue, is set the GITHUB_PER_PAGE in the worker service. If you're using docker-compose you can add a line here.
The default value is 50, but sometimes that causes issues with the GitHub API (a page of data may be too big and trip a timeout/error). I would suggest lowering it to 30 or even 10. This will make the sync running time longer, but may avoid some of these timeouts.
We are working on:

Configuration options per sync type (so that you can manage these parameters fora sync run in the UI)
Implementing API retries in our GitHub API syncs
Thanks let me try this and get back to you

Bot Handle  in issues and reactivity.

node.bodyText: hi @gedw99 just to clarify - do you mean identifying whether an issue was created by a bot? I will check in the GitHub API and see if they have a field for tracking that. I know bots often comment/open issues with a handle that has the string [bot]  in it, which could be identified in SQL using a string match or regular expression. We could put together some examples around that

Hey @patrickdevivo
sounds hopeful regarding string search of the contents of an issue. That’s what I was hoping was possible too.
I also would like to know what you suggest. Was an issue created by a bot.
Also I want to know when a human put a bot command handle into an issue comment.
Does that make it clearer ?
The intent is to be able to know:

when, who and the args of the bot that a human wrote into an issue.

Would be bonus if I was able to subscribe to a query from the cli or some daemon so that I get  new events of this type. I don’t know if your architecture supports this conceptually btw. I call them “Squeries”. Under the hood it could be a graphql subscription or a CDC running under postresql. I expect your architecture is a bit of a CQRS style setup and so the Squery would be possible to do using SQL.
sorry to ram so much into a single issue but I am hoping that it’s also welcome in terms of product extensibility.
